channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Shields Gay Rights Parade From Repeat of Violence
item.media:description: Gay rights activists marched through Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday, guarded by police and security forces. Though threats had been made beforehand, no violence was reported at the event.
item.description: A peaceful march attracting about 2,000 people in Kiev was a striking contrast to what happened last year, when members of far-right organizations attacked the 300 or so participants, injuring dozens.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA

item.title: As Strikes Continue in France, Garbage and Resentment Pile Up
item.media:description: Philippe Martinez, the head of a French worker’s union, spoke in front of a chemical factory in southern France on Saturday.
item.description: After terrorist attacks, floods and other labor strife, a walkout by trash workers was the latest insult just as the weather warmed and fans arrived for the European Championship soccer tournament.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Freed From Prison, Zainab al-Khawaja Flees Bahrain
item.media:description: The human rights activist Zainab al-Khawaja was released from prison in May, but fear of re-arrest has led her to flee Bahrain for Denmark.
item.description: Zainab al-Khawaja, imprisoned for opposing that country’s ruling monarchy, has left the Persian Gulf state in fear of being rearrested and separated from her son.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: China Tries to Redistribute Education to the Poor, Igniting Class Conflict
item.media:description: Students in Mianyang, China, did review work in May as they prepared for the national college entrance exam, known as the gaokao. The exam gives the admissions system a meritocratic sheen, but critics say it reinforces the divide between urban and rural students.
item.description: A plan to expand higher education to students from impoverished regions, at the expense of the urban middle class, has set off an intense backlash.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Explosion Wounds 4 at Airport in Shanghai
item.media:description: Paramilitary officers standing guard at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai after a blast that officials said was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.
item.description: The police said the blast, at a check-in counter in one of China’s busiest airports, was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Feature: Mecca Goes Mega
item.media:description: A view of the Grand Mosque from a Grand Royal Suite at the Fairmont Makkah Clock Royal Tower. The suite can cost $10,000 a night.
item.media:credit: Luca Locatelli/Institute, for The New York Times
item.description: A building boom in the city’s sacred center has created a dazzling, high-tech 21st-century pilgrimage.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by LUCA LOCATELLI

item.title: Bangladesh Arrests Over 3,000 to Halt Attacks
item.media:description: A crowd in Dhaka, Bangladesh, watching a police raid in February that was part of an effort to halt a wave of brutal attacks on minorities and activists.
item.description: The arrests were part of a series of raids intended to quell a wave of deadly machete attacks against bloggers, minorities and others, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: South Korean Families Watch Ferry’s Salvaging, Hoping Truth Surfaces
item.media:description: Oh Byung-hwan, left, whose son died in the 2014 Sewol ferry disaster, is among the relatives of victims who have camped out on Donggeochado, South Korea, to monitor the ship’s salvaging operation.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Distrustful of the government’s response to the 2014 Sewol disaster, victims’ families have camped out on a rocky island to monitor the salvage operation.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Doctor’s Plan for Full-Body Transplants Raises Doubts Even in Daring China
item.media:description: Dr. Ren Xiaoping, left, an orthopedic surgeon in Harbin, China, plans to carry out full-body transplants, raising concerns among medical experts and ethicists around the world.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Patients suffering from paralysis and muscular wasting diseases are enthusiastic, but medical experts say the idea is “at best premature and at worst reckless.”
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: ACT, Citing Breach, Cancels Exam in South Korea and Hong Kong
item.description: More than 5,000 students were prevented from taking the college entrance test on Saturday in what a spokesman said was the first known nationwide cancellation in its history.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: While Young Britons Favor Staying in E.U., They Aren’t Big on Voting
item.media:description: Supporters of the “Vote Remain” campaign in London. Young Britons are generally comfortable with a multicultural society, surveys have found, and they value the opportunity to work and travel in 28 European nations without a visa.
item.description: Holding the attention of young voters — and getting them to turn out on June 23 for a referendum on whether Britain should stay in the European Union — is a challenge.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Australia Reconsiders How Far Flight 370 May Have Flown
item.media:description: Technicians worked aboard the Fugro Equator, a ship searching for the remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, as it docked in Fremantle, Australia, in May.
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.description: As survey ships near the end of a search for the missing jet, officials take a last-ditch look at how far a plane might travel after using up its fuel.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: India Holds Suspect in Killing of Narendra Dabholkar, an Anti-Mystic Activist
item.media:description: Mourners paid their respects to Dr. Narendra Dabholkar in 2013.
item.description: The suspect, Virendra Tawde, is said to have clashed with Dr. Dabholkar over the physician’s crusade against spiritual practices he considered fraudulent.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Chinese Hackers in the Back Office
item.media:description: Cate Machine & Welding has allowed Area 1, a digital security company, to monitor the activity on a dusty, old server taken over by Chinese hackers so that potential victims of an attack can be warned.
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.description: A dusty old computer in a mom-and-pop Wisconsin welding shop is giving a digital security firm a window into the operations of Chinese hackers.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Greed, Passion, Lust, Betrayal, and the Olympics in Between
item.media:description: The actresses Nathalia Dill, left, and Juliana Carneiro da Cunha on the set of the telenovela “Liberdade, Liberdade,” at Globo’s studios in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: In Brazil, the popular TV serials called telenovelas have so tight a grip on viewers that even the Olympics on home turf take a back seat in prime time.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: A French Minister Who Attracts Applause and Anger Considers a Bigger Stage
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, center, the French economy minister, with José Ángel Gurría, left, secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, at a meeting this month in Paris.
item.description: Emmanuel Macron has started what many consider a campaign in all but name to explore whether to challenge François Hollande as the Socialist candidate for president.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: What in the World: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
item.media:description: A former German bunker in Mamerki, Poland. Researchers have uncovered evidence of a hidden chamber inside, and think it may contain loot from World War II.
item.description: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Chinese Delicacy Straight From the Swiftlet’s Mouth
item.media:description: A caretaker held a bird’s nest and egg at the Swiftlet Eco Park in Perak, Malaysia, last year. Prized in China for their alleged health benefits, nests made from swiftlets’ saliva are a delicacy.
item.description: Bird’s nest soup, including bird saliva, is supposed to improve the immune system, skin and sex drive. The demand means trouble for the birds themselves.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: An All-Purpose Maze Deep Beneath a London Suburb
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photos by Jag_cz, Andrey Yurlov, Ollie, Graeme Dawes/shutterstock
item.description: The Chislehurst Caves have been an arsenal, a bomb shelter, a concert site, a film set, and once even a makeshift maternity ward. But they’ve never been caves.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Exposures: The Child Migrants of Africa
item.media:description: Ablie, 17, Fodaoi, 14, and Alieu, 17, all from Gambia, at the center for unaccompanied minors in Pozzallo.
item.description: The Italian government has largely kept reporters from entering shelters and interviewing refugees.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY GILBERTSON
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Europe and the Unthinkable
item.description: The collapse of the European Union is implausible but not impossible. It is time to awaken to the dangers.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Common-Sense Steps to Deal With the Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants on the Italian Navy vessel Grecale off Sicily in May. In the first five months of this year, 48,000 migrants were rescued from the Canale di Sicilia section of the central Mediterranean.
item.description: People have been crossing the Mediterranean for years, trying to get to Italy. Why can’t the Continent come up with a good response?
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: ‘Named a Chevalier of the French Legion? Me?’ — Reporter’s Notebook.
item.media:description: Steven Erlanger, left, with the French diplomat Jean-David Levitte and America’s ambassador to France, Jane Hartley, at the United States embassy in Paris on June 2.
item.description: The former Paris bureau chief Steven Erlanger was surprised to learn he has been honored as a chevalier — or knight — by France.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
